#Text=Akinyele Umoja
#Text=Akinyele Umoja ( born 1954 ) is an American educator and author who specializes in African-American studies .
#Text=As an activist , he is a founding member of the New Afrikan People 's Organization and the Malcolm X Grassroots Movement . [ 1 ]
#Text=In April 2013 , New York University Press published Umoja 's book We Will Shoot Back : Armed Resistance in the Mississippi Freedom Movement .
#Text=Currently , he is a Professor and Department Chair of the Department of African-American Studies at Georgia State University ( GSU ) .
#Text=Early life and education
#Text=Akinyele Omowale Umoja was born in Los Angeles , California , in 1954 , and spent much of his childhood in Compton , California . [ 2 ]
#Text=He graduated from high school in 1972 . [ 3 ]
#Text=Umoja received his BA in Afro-American studies from California State University , Los Angeles , in June 1986 . [ 1 ]
#Text=He earned his M.A. in August 1990 at the Institute of Liberal Arts at Emory University in Atlanta , Georgia .
#Text=While a Ph.D. candidate at Emory under Robin Kelley , his dissertation topic was “ Eye for an Eye : Armed Resistance in the Mississippi Freedom Movement . ” [ 1 ]
#Text=Career
#Text=Early activism in California
#Text=Umoja has been active in the liberation struggle of Afrikan people , particularly working with the New Afrikan Independence Movement . [ 3 ]
#Text=After beginning to attend UCLA in 1972 , as a freshman , he began to write for the student newspaper NOMMO and also joined the Muhammad Ahmad ( Max Stanford ) Defense Committee ( MADC ) . [ 3 ]
#Text=When activist Ahmad was held on conspiracy charges , Umoja organized petitions and fundraisers to secure Ahmad 's release .
#Text=He dropped out of UCLA , also joining the African People 's Party and the House of Umoja .
#Text=Two years later , [ 3 ]
#Text=he was a founding member of the Malcolm X Grassroots Movement and the New Afrikan People 's Organization . [ 4 ]
#Text=Umoja has since represented both organizations nationally and in international forums in the Caribbean , Africa , and Europe . [ 4 ]
#Text=From 1972 until 1982 , Umoja was on the staff of Soulbook : The Revolutionary Journal of the Black World , founded by Mamadou Lumumba . [ 3 ]
#Text=He was also very active in activism in Los Angeles during this time , where he organized security and assistance for several of Malcolm X ’ s associates .
#Text=He was also active with the Coalition Against Police Abuse ( CAPA ) in Los Angeles . [ 3 ]

#Text=In 1979 , Umoja was in a committee of the National Black Human Rights Coalition , which produced a document “ detailing the Black liberation movement ’s demand for self-determination , reparations and a call to release political prisoners . ”
#Text=It was presented to the Secretary General of the United Nations at that time , who was Salim Salim of Tanzania . [ 3 ]
#Text=Career in education
#Text=Umoja has varied experiences as an educator .
#Text=He has taught in secondary schools , alternative schools , and colleges and universities , as well as developed Afrikan-centered curriculum for public schools and community-education programs .
#Text=In the late 1980s , he taught social studies in Atlanta 's public schools , where he also taught African-American history from 1986 until 1991 at the Atlanta Metropolitan College . [ 1 ]
#Text=In the early 1990s , he began teaching in the history department of Clark Atlanta University , where he lectured until 1996 . [ 1 ]
#Text=He then became a professor at the Department of African American Studies at Georgia State University ( GSU ) , [ 1 ] and is also department chair . [ 2 ]
#Text=Writing and recent appearances

#Text=Umoja 's writing has been featured in scholarly publications as The Journal of Black Studies , New Political Science , The International Journal of Africana Studies , Black Scholar , Radical History Review and Socialism and Democracy .

#Text=Umoja was one of the contributors to Blackwell Companion on African American History , The Black Panther Party Reconsidered , Liberation , Imagination , and the Black Panther Party , and Malcolm X : A Historical Reader .
#Text=In April 2013 , New York University Press published Umoja 's first single-authored book , which was titled We Will Shoot Back : Armed Resistance in the Mississippi Freedom Movement . [ 5 ]

#Text=A review in The Clarion-Ledger in 2015 described the book as following “ confrontations in communities across the state through the end of the 1970s , demonstrating how black Mississippians were ultimately able to overcome intimidation by mainstream society , defeat legal segregation , and claim a measure of political control of their state . ” [ 6 ]
#Text=He was honored for the book in 2014 in Oakland . [ 7 ]
#Text=Umoja has been a contributor to commercial and popular documentaries on black history .
#Text=Umoja was a featured commentator on the American Gangster episode “ Dr. Mutulu Shakur , ” which aired on November 8 , 2008 .
#Text=He also appears in Bastards of the Party ( 2006 ) and Freedom Archives ’ Cointelpro 101 ( 2010 ) .

#Text=In recent years , he supported movements in Guyana and Haiti , and , in August 2010 , he led a Black August delegation of the Malcolm X Grassroots Movement to Haiti to investigate conditions after a recent earthquake . [ 3 ]
#Text=In 2013 , he lectured in Mississippi on the 1965 boycott by black citizens . [ 8 ]
#Text=In 2014 , he offered the solemn libations in honor of his late friend Chokwe Lumumba at the mayor 's funeral in Jackson , Mississippi . [ 9 ] [ 10 ] [ 11 ]
#Text=Awards and recognition
#Text=He earned the Patricia Harris Fellowship from 1990 until 1993 , and , in 1994 , he was named in Who ’s Who in America ’s Teachers . [ 1 ]
#Text=In 1995 , he was an honorary member of the National Golden Key Honor Society . [ 1 ]

#Text=We Will Shoot Back : Armed Resistance in the Mississippi Freedom Movement
